lines.text:
[to Gaear]
So, that was Mrs. Lundegaard on the floor in there. And I guess that was your accomplice in the wood chipper. And those three people in Brainerd. And for what? For a little bit of money? There's more to life than a little money, you know. Don'tcha know that? And here ya are, and it's a beautiful day. Well. I just don't understand it.
Say, Lou, didya hear the one about the guy who couldn't afford personalized plates, so he went and changed his name to J3L2404?
Yah, that's a good one.
You're darn tootin'!
I'm not sure I agree with you a hundred percent on your police work, there, Lou.
[Marge bends over next to the overturned car, as if she's looking at something on the ground]
You alright there, Margie?
Oh, I just think I'm gonna barf...

[standing up again after a moment]
... Well, that passed. Now I'm hungry again.
There's a minimum charge of four dollars. Long-term parking charges by the day.

I guess you think you're... you know, like an authority figure, with that stupid fuckin' uniform, huh buddy? King clip-on-tie there, big fuckin' man, huh? You know these are the limits of your life, man! The rule of your little fuckin' gate here!
[gives the attendant the money]
Here's your four dollars, you pathetic piece of shit!
Who the fuck are you?
[Wade doesn't answer]
WHO THE FUCK ARE YOU?
I got your damn money. Now, where's my daughter?
I am through fuckin' around here! Drop that fuckin' briefcase!
Where's my daughter?
Fuck you, man! Where's Jerry? I gave simple fuckin' instructions!
Where's my damn daughter? No Jean, no money!
Drop that fuckin' money!
No Jean, no money!
Is this a fuckin' joke here?
[shoots Wade]

[as he sinks to his knees and falls back]
Aww, Jeez.
Happy now, asshole? What's with you people? Ya fuckin' imbeciles!
[as Carl reaches for the briefcase, Wade shoots him in the face]
Ah! You fuckin' shot me!
[Carl shoots Wade six more times, screams, then kicks the dead Wade twice]
You fuck!
[takes briefcase]

So, I'm tendin' bar there at Ecklund and Swedlin's last Tuesday, and this little guy's drinkin' and he says, "So where can a guy find some action? I'm goin' crazy out there at the lake." And I says, "What kinda action?" and he says, "Woman action, what do I look like?" And I says, "Well, what do I look like? I don't arrange that kinda thing," and he says, "But I'm goin' crazy out there at the lake," and I says, "Well, this ain't that kinda place."
Uh-huh.
So he angrily says, "Oh I get it, so you think I'm some kinda crazy jerk for askin'!" only he doesn't use the word "jerk."
I understand.

And then he calls me a jerk, and says that the last guy who thought he was a jerk is dead now. So I don't say nothin' and he says, "What do ya think about that?" So I says, "Well, that don't sound like too good a deal for him, then."

[chuckles]
Ya got that right.
And he says, "Yah, that guy's dead, and I don't mean of old age." And then he just pays his tab and walks out saying, "Geez, I'm goin' crazy out there at the lake!"
White Bear Lake?
Well... Ecklund & Swedlin's, that's closer ta Moose Lake, so I made that assumption.
Oh sure.

So, ya know, he's drinkin', so I don't think a whole great deal of it, but Mrs. Mohra heard about the homicides down here last week and she thought I should call it in. So... I called it in. End o' story.
What'd this guy look like, anyway?
Oh, he was a little guy... Kinda funny lookin'.
Uh-huh. In what way?
Oh, just in a general kinda way.
[Jean is making noise in the back of the car]
Shut the fuck up! Or I'll throw you back in the trunk, you know?
Jesus, that's more than I've heard you say all week.
Ah, hon, ya got Arby's all over me.
Oh for Pete's sake, he's fleeing the interview! He's fleeing the interview!
They announced it.
They announced it?
Yeah.
So?
Three-cent stamp.
Your mallard?
Yeah.
Oh, that's terrific.
It's just a three-cent stamp.
It's terrific.
Hautman's blue-winged teal got the 29-cent. People don't much use the three-cent.
Oh, for Pete's sake. Of course they do. Whenever they raise the postage, people need the little stamps.

[Jerry and Wade discuss business opportunity]
This could work out real good for me and Jean and Scotty.

[coldly]
Jean and Scotty never have to worry.

[irately, over the phone]
Alright, Jerry, I'm through fuckin' around! You got the fuckin' money?

[into the phone]
Yeah, I got the money, but... uh...
Don't you fuckin' fuck me, Jerry! I want you to get this money to the parking garage at the Dayton Radisson, top level, in 30 minutes, Jerry. We wrap this thing up.
Yeah, but...

Hey, you're there in 30 minutes, Jerry, or I find you, Jerry, and I shoot you and I shoot your fuckin' wife and I shoot all your fuckin' children and I shoot them all in the back of their little fuckin' heads! You got it?
Okay, now you stay away from Scotty, now.
Well, that's it then. Here are the keys.
No, that's not it, Jerry.
Huh?
The new vehicle plus $40,000.
Yah, the deal was the car first then the $40,000 as if it was the ransom. I thought Shep told you that.
Yah, I'm sorry. That was a mix up.
Yeah, you already said that.
Yah, but this is not a whole pay in advance deal. You see, I give you a brand new vehicle in advance and...
I'm not gonna debate you, Jerry.
Okay.
I'm not gonna sit here and debate.

[answering the phone]
Jerry Lundegaard.

[voice over the phone]
Alright, Jerry, you got the phone to yourself? Are you alone?

[into the phone]
Well, yeah.

[voice]
You know who this is?
Well, yeah, I got an idea. How's that Ciera working out for ya?

[voice]
Circumstances have changed, Jerry.
Well, what do ya mean?

[voice]
Things have changed, circumstances, Jerry... force majeure, acts of God.
How's Jean?

[puzzled]
Who's Jean?
My wife! What the-?

[voice]
Oh... right. She's alright, but there's a few people in Brainerd who aren't so okay, I'll tell you that.
What the heck are ya talking about? Let's just finish this deal up here.

[voice]
Blood has been shed, Jerry.
What the heck do ya mean?

[voice]
Three people, in Brainerd... are dead.
Oh, jeez!

[voice]
That's right, we need more money.
What the heck are ya talking about? What do you fellas have yourself mixed up in?

[voice]
Never mind that. We need more money...

[interrupting]
This was supposed to be a no rough stuff type deal!

[angry]
DON'T EVER INTERRUPT ME, JERRY! JUST SHUT THE FUCK UP!
Well, I'm sorry, but I just... I don't...

[voice]
I'm not gonna debate with you on this, Jerry! I'm not gonna debate! Three people in Brainerd were killed last night. We now want the entire 80,000!
Oh, for chris'sake here!
You're a smooth smoothie, you know?
I love you, Margie.
I love you, Norm.
[she leaves, closing the door; after getting in the car briefly, she comes back in the door]
Hon?
Yah?
Prowler needs a jump.
[Marge is interviewing the two hookers whose clients were the two suspects]
Well, the little guy was kinda funny-lookin'.
In what way?
I dunno... just funny-lookin'.
Can you be any more specific?
I couldn't really say... He wasn't circumcised.

[amused by this unhelpful detail]
Was he funny lookin' apart from that?
Yah...
So, you were havin' sex with the little fellow, then.
Uh huh...
Mind if I sit down? I'm carrying quite a load here.
[last lines]

[rubbing Margie's pregnant stomach]
Two more months.

[smiling]
Two more months.

[entering cabin, with shot-up face]
You should see the other guy.

[he sees Jean Lundegaard's dead body]
What the fuck happened to her?

[watching TV and eating TV dinner]
Uh, she started shrieking, y'know. She wouldn't stop...
Geesus. Well, it doesn't matter. I got the money. All of it. All eighty grand.

[he puts a couple stacks of bills down on table]
That's forty for you, forty for me.
[Grimsrud pokes at the stacks of bills with his fork]

[puts a set of keys next to the money]
That's it, then. You can have my truck. Here's the keys. I'm takin' the Ciera.
We split that.

[pause]
How the fuck do you split a fuckin' car, ya dummy? With a fuckin' chainsaw?
One of us pays the other for half.

Hold on! No fuckin' way! You fuckin' notice this? I got fuckin' shot! I got fuckin' shot in the face! I went and got the fuckin' money. I got shot fuckin' picking it up! I've been up for thirty-six fuckin' hours! I'm taking' that fuckin' car! That fucker's mine, you fuckin' asshole!
[as usual, no response from Grimsrud]
You know, I've been listening to your fuckin' bullshit all week! Are we square?
[no response from Grimsrud who continues staring at the TV]

[flashing his gun]
Are WE square?
[no response]
Yeah, ya fuckin' mute. And if you see your friend Shep Proudfoot, tell him I'm gonna nail his fuckin' ass!
[he exits angrily toward the Ciera; after a few seconds, Grimsrud follows him out the door with an axe in hand]

[Showalter turns and sees Grimsrud striding toward him, axe raised]
Oh no! Aaaaaah!
[Grimsrud brings the axe down toward Carl's neck]
[repeated line]
The heck do ya mean?
[first lines]
I'm, uh, Jerry Lundegaard.
You're Jerry Lundegaard?
Ya. Shep Proudfoot said...
30. What gives, man?
We've been sitting here an hour. He's
[motioning to Gaer]
peed three times already.
30. It was a mix-up, I guess.
But you're sayin'... what are ya sayin'?
How was everything today?

[Shep Proudfoot, enraged, bursts into apartment and knocks Carl out of bed while having sex with hooker]
Shep, whatthefuckyadoin'? I'm banging that girl!
You ever been to Minneapolis?
Nope.
Would it... kill you to say something?
I did.
"No." That's the first thing you've said in the last four hours. That's, a fountain of conversation there, buddy. That's a geyser.

[beating Carl Showalter violently]
Fucking little weasel! Fuck you! You fucking motherfucker son of a bitch! Fucking cock! Jesus Christ! You fucking shitbag motherfucker!
I decided not to park there.

Would it... kill you to say something? "No." That's the first thing you've said in the last four hours. That's a... that's fountain of conversation, man. That's a geyser. I mean, whoa daddy! Stand back, man. Shit. I'm sitting here driving. Doing all the driving, man. The whole fucking way from Brainard driving. Just trying to... chat, you know. Keep our spirits up, fight the boredom of the road, and you can't say one fucking thing just in the way of conversation. Oh fuck it. I don't have to talk to you either, man. See how you like it. Just total fucking silence. Two can play at that game, smart guy. We'll just see how you like it. Total silence.
Where is pancakes house?
What?
We stop at pancakes house.
What... are you nuts? We had pancakes for breakfast. Gotta go to a place I can get a shot and a beer, steak, maybe, not more fuckin' pancakes, c'mon.
[Gaear just stares at Carl]
we can stop outside of Brainerd. I know a place there we can get laid. Whaddya think?
I'm fucking hungry now, you know!
Yeah yeah Jesus, I'm sayin' we can... stop, get pancakes and then we'll get laid, alright?
[Gaear glares briefly]

[finishing supper]
May I be excused?
Ya done, there?
Yah. Can I go out?
Where ya goin'?
Just to McDonalds.
[Scotty exits]
He just ate - he didn't finish! He's goin' to McDonalds instead of finishin' here.
He sees his friends there. It's okay.
It's okay, MAC-Donalds. Heh. Whaddya think they do there? They don't drink milkshakes, I assure you.
It's okay, Dad!

[reprimanding Scotty, who is eating and watching TV, paying no attention]
I am talking about your potential. You're not a 'C' student.
Uh huh...
Yet you're gettin' 'C' grades. It's the disparity here that concerns your dad and me.

[mumbling]
Mmmm.
Ya know what a disparity is?

[attentive now]
Yeah!
Okay, then! That's why we don't want ya goin' out for hockey!

[upset]
Oh, come on! What's the big deal? It's just an hour a... what's the big deal?

[phone rings]
Hold on.
[answers phone]
Hullo? Oh, hi, Dad! Yah! He's here, I'll catch him for ya!

[to Jerry]
Hon, it's Dad.

[to his father, entering the room]
Look, Dad, there's no fucking way...

[putting his hand over the phone's mouthpiece]
Hey, let's watch that language there!

[on date with hooker]
So, how long you been with the escort service?
I don't know, a few months.
Find that work interesting, do ya?
What're you talkin' about?
[quick cut to next scene, where he's having sex with her]
Well, I'm sorry, sir!

[storming off to do a lot count]
Aw, what the Chris'!
You betcha!
[Jerry and an irate customer argue over a sealant that the customer had previously indicated he didn't want, after Jerry has gone off to pretend to talk to his boss]
Well, we've never done this before. But seeing as it's special circumstances and all, he says I can knock a hundred dollars off that Trucoat.

[stunned that Jerry still intends to charge him for something he didn't order]
One hundred... You lied to me, Mr. Lundegaard. You're a bald-faced liar. A... fucking liar.

[to his wife, frustrated]
Where's my goddamn checkbook? Let's get this over with.
I told ya. We haven't had any vehicles go missing.
Okay! But are ya sure? 'Cause I mean, how do you know? Do you do a count, or what kind of a routine do you have here?

[growing uncomfortable with this questioning]
Ma'am, I answered your question!

[long pause]
I'm sorry, sir?
Ma'am, I answered your question! I answered the darned... I'm cooperatin' here!
Sir, you have no call to get snippy with me! I'm just doing my job here.
I'm... I'm not arguing here! I'm cooperating. So there's no need to... we're doin' all we can here.
Sir, could I talk to Mr. Gustafson?
[Jerry gives her a glassy-eyed look, knowing full well that Gustafson is dead]
Mr. Lundegaard?

[reporting over her police radio]
There's the car! There's the car!
What car?
My car, my car! Tan Ciera, tan Ciera!
I need unguent.
Oh, fuck it, I don't have to talk, either, man! See how you like it. Just total fuckin' silence. Two can play at that game, smart guy. We'll just see how you like it. Total silence.
OK, so we got a trooper pulls someone over, we got a shooting, these folks drive by, there's a high-speed pursuit, ends here and then this execution-type deal.
Just keep it still back there, lady, or we're going to have to, you know, shoot you.
[as Shep angrily approaches Carl]
You stay away from me, man! Hey, smoke a fuckin' peace pipe!

[moves to Marge's side of the table and puts arms around her]
Do you mind if I sit over here?
No. Why don't you sit over there? I'd prefer that.
Huh? Uh... ok.
[moves back to other side of table]
Sorry.
Oh, no, no. Just so I can see you. I don't have to turn my neck.
I'm not talking about your damn word, Jerry.

[voice]
Three people were killed last night in Brainerd. We're in a load of trouble, Jerry. I'm comin' there tomorrow. You have the money ready by then.

[into the phone]
Now, we had a deal. A deal's a deal.

[voice]
Is it, Jerry? Why don't you ask those three poor souls in Brainerd if a deal's a deal? Go ahead, ask them!

[into the phone]
The heck do ya mean?

[mimicking Jerry mockingly]
"The heckya mean?" I'll call you tomorrow!
[hangs up]

[on lobby phone, asking advice about a restaurant]
Is it reasonable?
You know, it's proven that second-hand smoke is, uh, carcin-... uh, you know, cancer related.
I'm in a bit of trouble...
What kind of trouble are you in, Jerry?
Well, that's, that's... I'm not gonna go into, inta... see, I just need money.
Well, heck! If you wanna... If you wanna play games here, I'm working with ya on this thing here, but... Okay!
[slams table as he stands up]
I'll do a damn lot count!
Sir, right now?
Yeah! Right now. You're darn tootin'! If it's so damned important to ya!
You see, my wife's dad is real well off.
So, why don't you just ask him for the money?
Or your fucking wife, you know.
Or your fuckin' wife, Jerry?

Well, it's all part of... look, the thing is they don't know that I'm in trouble. My wife and father-in-law don't know I need money. And if they did... I still won't get it. Okay? These are personal matters.
Personal matters? Okay, you're tasking us to perform this mission, but you won't tell us what... oh, fuck it. Let's have a look at the Ciera.
Whoa Daddy.

[banging on the TV]
Come on, plug me into the ozone, baby, come on!
So, Mike, should we get together another time?
No!
[sobs]
I'm sorry, I... I shouldn't have done this. I shouldn't have done this, I shouldn't have... I thought we'd have a really terrific time.
It's OK, Mike.
You were such a super lady... and I'm, I'm so lonely.
[sobs]

[to Radisson hotel concierge]
I'm doing really super there, thanks. I am Mrs. Gunderson. I have a reservation.
Yep, you sure do, Mrs. Gunderson.

[smiling]
Is there a phone down here, you think?
Hon? Prowler needs a jump.
[repeated line]
Oh yah!

[voice]
Mr. Lundegaard? This is Reilly Diefenbach from GMAC. How are you this morning?

[into the phone]
Real good. How are you?

[voice]
Pretty good, Mr. Lundegaard. I must say, you are damn hard to get a hold of over the phone.
Well, we're pretty darn busy here, but that's the way we like it.

[voice]
Well, that's for sure. The reason why I've been trying to reach you is that these last financing documents that you sent over to us... I can't read the serial numbers of the vehicles...

[getting nervous]
Yah, well I already got the money. The loans are in place. I already got the...

[voice]
Yah, the 320 thousand... you got the money last month from us.
So, we're all set then.

[voice]
Yah, but the vehicles that you're borrowing on, I just can't read the serial numbers on your application. Maybe if you could just read...
Yah, but the deal's already done. I've already got the money.

[voice]
Yah, but we have an audit here and I just have to know that these vehicles that your financing with this money that they really exist.

[getting more nervous]
Well... they exist all right.

[voice]
Well, I'm pretty sure they do, but I can't read the serial numbers here. Maybe if you could read the numbers to me on the first...
Yah... well... see... I don't have them in front of me. Why don't I just fax you over a copy?

[voice]
No, no, a fax is no good. That's what I have here and I can't read the darn thing.
Yah, I'll have my girl sent you a copy.

[voice]
Okay, that's good. But I need to tell you that if I can't correlate these numbers with those specific vehicles, then I'm gonna have to call back all that money.
How much money did you say that was?

[voice]
$320,000. I have to correlate that money with the cars that it's being lent on.
Okay, no problem. I'll just fax...

[voice]
No, no...
I mean send it right over. I'll shoot it right over. Good bye.
[hangs up]

[Jerry just got off the phone with a furious Carl who demanded the entire $80,000 instead of the $40,000 that was promised after him and Gaear killed three people in Brainerd when the phone goes again]
Yah!

[over the phone]
Jerome Lundegaard.

[slightly friendlier]
Yah.

[over the phone]
This is Reilly Diefenbach of the GMAC. Sir, I've not received those vehicle ID's you promised.
Yah, I... those are in the mail.

[over the phone]
That very well may be. I must inform you, however, that absent the receipt of those numbers by tomorrow afternoon I will have to refer this matter to our legal department.
Yah.

[over the phone]
My patience is at an end.
Yah.

[over the phone]
Good day, Sir.
Yah.
[Jerry hangs up the phone and then suddenly throws things off his desk in a fit of rage]
So, do you remember getting a phone call Wednesday night?

[after a short pause]
No.
You do reside there at 1425 Freemont Terrace?
Yes.
Anyone else residing there?
No.

Well, Mr. Proudfoot, this call came in past three in the morning. It's just hard for me to believe you don't remember anyone calling your place at that time. Now, I know you have some problems; struggling with the narcotics, smothering tank, currently on parole.
So?

Well, associating with criminals if you're the one they talked to... that right there would be a violation of your parole. Would land you back in stillbar. Now, I saw some rough stuff on your priors, but nothing in the nature of a homicide. I know you don't want to be an accessory to something like that.
[after another pause]
So... you think you remember anything about those folks who called ya now?
So, uh, you married old Norm son-of-a-Gunderson?
Hiya, Norm. How ya doin', Margie? How's the fricasse?
Pretty darn good, ya want some?
No, I gotta - hey, Norm, I thought you were goin' fishin' up at Mille Lacs?
Yah, after lunch.

[chopping vegetables]
Hiya, hon! Welcome back! How was Fargo?
Yah, real good now.
Dad's here.
[Jerry's mood changes as he hears this news]
Is he stayin' for supper then?
I dunno... I think so. Dad?
What?

[thick Minnesota accent]
You stayin' for supperrrrr?
Yah!

[sitting up in bed, while Norm lies next to her, sleeping]
Norm?

[Norm wakes up]
Yeah, Marge?
I'm turning in now.

[to Carl after he inadvertently put a police chief on Shep's trail who's an ex-con]
Fuckin' asshole!

[after being bit on the hand by Jean Lindegaard]
Unguen... I need Unguen.
[repeated line]
We're not a bank, Jerry.
[repeated line]
I'm not gonna debate you.
[repeated line]
I'll fix you some eggs.
[repeated line]
No Jean, no money!
We sat right here, in this room, and went over this and over this.
Yeah, but that TruCoat...
I sat right here and said I didn't want any TruCoat.
Yeah, but I'm saying that TruCoat. You don't get it, you get oxidation problems. It'll cost you a heck of a lot more than $500.
You're sitting there. You're talking in circles. You're talking like we didn't go over this already.
Yeah, but this TruCoat...
We had a deal here for nineteen-five. You sat there and darned if you didn't tell me you'd get me this car, these options, without the sealant for nineteen-five.
All right, I'm not saying I didn't...

You called me 20 minutes ago and said you had it ready to make delivery! You says, "Come on down and get it." And, and, and here you are and you're wasting my time and my wife's time, and I'm paying nineteen-five for this vehicle here!
All right. I'll talk to my boss.
[gets up and turns before leaving]
See, they install that TruCoat at the factory. There's nothing we can do about that.
[Customer ready to shout]
but I'll talk to my boss.
These guys here. These guys. It's always the same! It's always more!
